Posts.Content: Hi Shirl, Your post about being able to stay in in Edinburgh, eased my mind quite a bit, thank you! And when I had my second ultrasound yesterday, to check lymph nodes, (which radiologist thought looked alright), he said they could perhaps do a push(?) regime, a higher dose, for shorter time. They still don't know what cancer type I have though, radiologist said he has never seen it before, as it seems to be mainly in the skin, so I now have to go for an MRI in Edinburgh. I live near Coldstream and retired up here 4 years ago, so I don't know many people - Billy No Mates me! It has never worried me before, as I love living on my own (my brothers live in Australia), mainly just researching family history. I do plan to go to/ring GP surgery to ask re volunteer drivers for the operation, after CNS rings Monday to tell me what's next. There is also a Berwickshire group but although I am in a Scottish GP practice, I live in Northumberland, so not sure if covered. I'll sort it somehow....... Best wishes, Jan
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hi, I've been lurking in this group since January, from the Vulval one which I joined last year after having VIN2/3 which is just being watched at present. In Aug 2014 I found a tiny lump the size of a grain of rice in my right breast, which turned out to be just a cyst. It started growing slowly (which I'd read was normal), but about 8 months ago it started turning hard, and then I realised it no longer moved. Also I couldn't feel under it when doing self exams, and it was protruding from the skin a bit, so thought I'd better finally have it drained & went to GP for referral back to breast Clinic. Surgeon said it would be like cheese, and too thick to drain now, so did another mammogram, nothing showed, then ultrasound, which did, but radiologist said he didn't know what it was, and they needed to take a biopsy, which they did and said to see Clinical Nurse Specialist for results in 10 days. She rang on morning of appt to say results not back yet, to save me the 2 hour round trip, which I really appreciated. Although I had been googling on here and other cancer and dermatology sites (have a science background so want to know exactly what is going on), I couldn't find any precise explanation of what it could be either as cancer or not. So went along for results Mon 29th Feb, thinking I'd been over dramatizing, and it would be nothing, but was told grade 2 invasive carcinoma, ER+, HER- at present but they were still looking at the biopsy. Going for underarm lymph node ultrasound Friday 4th, then probable WLE 2 weeks after results. Feeling rather detached about it all so far, although I expect that may change. I've always been very independent, and hate asking for help, but logistics of getting to & from hosp (I live alone in the country), especially if need R/T which means longer trip to Edinburgh are my main worries as I can't sort them out. The CNS said take each step at a time, as we find out results, which I'm tring to do, but just a bit annoyed that as cysts are uncommon apparently in postmenopausal women (I'm 64), why was I not followed up earlier. Has anyone else had this happen to them?
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hi Shirl, I'm glad you've come through all your treatments, and are back at work now. BGH is my 'local' hospital too, and I usually drive, but need to plan what to do when have surgery & can't for a while. I did mention it to breast CNS but had no answers yet. One step at a time...... I hate driving so the thought of going to Edin 5 hour round trip for RT daily is making me think of opting for mastectomy over lumpectomy so wouldn't need it, but I see you had RT anyway. Overthinking again! Can I ask what type you had? And why surgery in Edin not BGH? Axillary ultrasound tomorrow will provide a few more answers.... Jan
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hi JJ1212, Ah yes, that loop is very hard to stop, especially in the small hours. We do seem to be similar cases, can I ask how old you were when the cyst was found? I hope you are doing well now though. Best wishes, Jan

Posts.Content: Hi JJ1212, Ah yes, that loop is very hard to stop, especially in the small hours. We do seem to be similar cases, can I ask how old you were when the cyst was found? I hope you are doing well now though. Best wishes, Jan
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Hi factseeker and tessiecat1, Sorry to hear you've both been in limboland re results and diagnosis too. I didn't have biopsy on the cyst originally as they just said it was benign. I am trying not to blame anyone, as I'd have to include me ie why didn't I lose that extra weight, exercise more, etc as that doesn't get you anywhere, and I'm trying to stay positive and not dwell on things, although it has been good to get things off my chest, even if figuratively at this stage. I'm reading a book on Mindfulness, and even bought a colouring book for when thoughts really start to kick in though! Best wishes, and hugs for both of you, and thanks for replying.

Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Love it! I remember seeing a program on TV a year or so ago about dogs being trained to recognise cancer, and even met a Trainee one in Sainsburys a couple of months later. It looked at me interestingly while I asked the owner about it, so I wonder if it smelt anything on me then???? Another what if? scenario better not to dwell on! Best wishes to all
Posts.Title: Weird sense of smell ?

Posts.Content: Hi French and Lacomtekp and other Evonail users, I bought some of the Evaux Evonail Soins des Ongles Reparateur,  and the Nettoyant Cleanser, after reading your posts (from Farmaline in the end who had given me a link to the US Evonail site but never had any reply from them -the site still says 2014!). I started using it 2 weeks ago, twice a day, and remove it weekly, followed by Mavala hardener, then Almond oil throughout the day, till I start painting again at night after using the Nettoyant again. However the cleanser doesn't seem to remove the Evonail polish itself, no matter how much I use/scrub/have soaked my nails in warm water beforehand, and I have to resort to non-acetone polish remover. Have I been applying it too thickly do you think? Any other suggestions greatly appreciated..... Good wishes to you all, Jan x
Posts.Title: Evonail, again

Posts.Content: Thanks Sarah, The instructions, as well as what I read on here, say twice a day so I did that. Perhaps I'm only using 2 or 3 blobs of the cleanser for all my nails, so will try 1 for each, and just sit down with a bowl of water on my lap, and be relaxed about it. The rigmarole of everything takes so long to do, doesn't it? I take an hour and a half to get ready in the mornings now, even without hair! Fingers crossed for your next Tax, Jan xxx
Posts.Title: Evonail, again

Posts.Content: I guess the clinic must see the results of its use, so if they said once a day, perhaps that's enough. Maybe you could try once a day on 1 hand/foot and twice on the other........ Jan xxx
Posts.Title: Evonail, again

Posts.Content: Best wishes for your op tomorrow.  x
Posts.Title: Pre-op nerves

Posts.Content: Hi lovely ladies, I hope you can help with a seemingly silly, small, and possibly, vain question! I was diagnosed last week grade 2 invasive, ER+,HER-, they're not sure what type but it has some lobular features so MRI scan on both breasts on 18th, lymph nodes on ultrasound seemed clear. Originally was told probable WLE, losing nipple, and probable Sentinel node biopsy, and hormone tabs. How long after surgery were you able to hold a hairdryer for 5-10 minutes (I have a bob that has just taken a year to grow!)?. I have dry shampoo at the ready, but am wondering should I just have my hair cut very short beforehand. Chemo hasn't been mentioned yet, if it had I'd definitely cut. Best wishes to you all,
Posts.Title: Trying to be practical

Posts.Content: Hmmm, that image file didn't come out the way I expected, as I just wanted the picture to show. What did I do wrong Dreamthief? Jan
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi Skye, How absolutely awful for you on top of everything else. I am just flabbergasted they could treat you so. I don't have words to express more but please envelop yourself in a virtual hug from everybody here. Love, Jan xxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Oh Skye01, my heart goes out to you. Just when we thought you'd been able to turn things around. Would it be better on yourself to just not see any of your family for a while, say you've had enough of their selfishness/non support, and that you need to focus on getting better yourself. Think I'd ask your niece to move out now too, if she is absolutely no help at all, and just dragging you down. Ignore them! I wonder if it is because what your family may have said to shop staff, that makes you think they are staring, or is it just because they are sympathetic that you have cancer, but are awkward in how to deal with it or discuss it (as most people are). Just smile at them and be pleasant, and carry on as normal with them, and you may find they'll respond. It also may be that your family are at a loss how to deal with your cancer too, everyone reacts differently. Although from what you've said, perhaps not, if they've always been like that. When my brother came over from Oz to look after me after my mastectomy in May, I felt he was being a bit flippant at times and not caring, but when I mentioned it (after much soul searching, as I am NOT good with expressing my feelings), he said that was how he has coped with things his whole life. And I thought he had just been easy going, always a joker..... We've lived over 1000 miles apart since I was 22, so never had time really to discuss things. Have you made an appointment with your BCN to see what support she can give you or refer you to? Like complementary therapies, counselling, other practical help? Give Macmillan a ring too/again even just for a chat to make you feel better. Hang in there, Love and hugs, Jan xxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: I also went on my own to get my biopsy results, and asked if I could record what the breast care nurse said on my phone, when she said yes to. It was so helpful, as although I knew what to expect, and had questions to ask and thought I took it all in, when I listened back I had forgotten a couple of things she said, and also realised that I took a couple of things she said in slightly the wrong way. Don't worry about questions to ask (you may not need to with any luck), as she will explain everything, and will give you a card with her phone/email, on how to contact her if you have questions you think of later. Best wishes
Posts.Title: Waiting is nearly over

Posts.Content: Hi gail259, Not in the same boat re oncotype test results, but can identify with feeling fed up re waiting, as I was diagnosed 29 Feb and still have no treatment plan. Have had 2nd ultrasound, an MRI and just told an hour ago I need to have another ultrasound on Friday! Still, the house might be sparkling by the time surgery finally happens, so I hope you can find something too to help take your mind off things, and that other ladies can help. Best wishes
Posts.Title: THE WAITING !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, Is the Pom written in capitals ie POM enclosed in a box on the packet which usually means Prescription Only Medicine? The information leaflet inside will usually have the brand on it as well, if it is unclear on the packet. Hope you get on well with whichever brand it is, best wishes
Posts.Title: New brand of letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi dollydaydream01, I'm working my way through discovering what helps with the disgusting taste too, and am also coming up for my 3rd FEC-T out of 6 next week So far, anything with ginger helps -biscuits, ginger ale, ginger tea, ginger icecream. Polo mints -anything mint really but only helps for a while. Cinnamon Sweet things (don't go overboard!) but apparently they counteract the bitter taste according to a book I just read about yesterday written by a chef at a cancer centre Rebecca Katz "The Cancer Fighting Kitchen". Available on amazon but a bit pricey, although you can download some of the recipes from her website. I might try some when I feel like cooking! See below about it https://www.fredhutch.org/en/news/center-news/2014/05/Combating-chemo-mouth-experts-offer-tips.html I've cut out everything with artificial sweeteners in - diet drinks, yogurts etc as they seem to make things worse, and have gone back to (low) sugar varieties, lol. And drink gallons, OK litres, of water...... Best wishes,
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: JayPee What I found helped was changing to a natural, non-foaming toothpaste. I bought fennel flavour without fluoride and could actually taste it. The flavour I picked was just because it was something I'd never had in a toothpast.  Hi Jim, That sounds interesting, love fennel/aniseed flavour. What brand/where did you buy it? Might try something aniseed flavoured to eat first to make sure it still tastes OK before I go ahead and buy it though! Best wishes, Jan
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, I can so relate to you! I went to GP Jan 11th, and still waiting on surgery, let alone anything else! Have needed scan after scan, and thought I was holding up well until I had a meltdown on Friday. Not like me at all. I hope you have a chemo date soon! Hugs, Jan
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: So glad to hear that something is starting to happen for you. Best wishes for chemo x
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: Looks perfect to me too! Jan xx
Posts.Title: Any advise re a mini cruise (GB)

Posts.Content: Looking at the actual trial, it looks like it is saying 10 years total on Letrozole gives 34% decrease in risk of recurrence. The 15 years related to those who had taken Tamoxifen 5 years before going on it.
Posts.Title: AI's for up to 15 yrs

Posts.Content: Hi Fluff99, that is reassuringly quite high, and they say they can't predict full 100%. It also doesn't include radiotherapy if they advise that too. I had 4 nodes affected, strongly ER+ and am older than you at 64, but you may have just to think that you could be one of those 3 extra women that survive. I've just had 3 cycles of FEC chemo, which was easier than I expected luckily with few side-effects, and another 3 Taxol to go, but if you found the chemo too hard, maybe they could stop it as you have such a high benefit already. It is good to try and have as much info as you can, so you can be comfortable with your decision. If your onco has said go ahead, well that is his expert opinion, and I'd be persuaded by that. Good luck, Jan
Posts.Title: Breast Tissue

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, I followed your link to the PubMed article which interested me, and then went on to find the outcome of the trial. Unfortunately it showed in over 3000 women followed for 7 years that increased vegetables (5 a day), 3 fruit, low fat(15-20%, 30g fibre plus 16 oz vegetable juice daily did not reduce further breast cancer events or mortality compared with those who did not. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17635889 However, it is a sensible way to eat even for other things and would make you feel good, and that can't be bad, although the pint of vegetable juice I might find a bit hard.
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, Another success story....... my maternal aunt had breast cancer in 1989 aged 70,after years of having lumps removed (not sure exactly what they were, as she was very private person). She had lumpectomy & radiotherapy, but got it again in other breast 2 years later. Radiotherapy again, then she had uterine cancer not long after, although not sure what treatment she had then. But she lived until she was 96, dying from something unconnected. She played tennis once or twice weekly all her life till she was about 75, had a sherry, or two, at 5pm every day, later it was whisky. So did one trade off the other????? Best to all, Jan xx
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: What time do they say the benefit is over? Is it 5 or 10 years? Mine was only 2.1% at 5 years, so I wondered whether it was worth it ,but after 10 years it was 5.3 %, taking me to over 82% survival, so I reckoned it was worth it (with hormonal therapy as well). Best wishes
Posts.Title: Breast Tissue

Posts.Content: My chemo was stopped 3 weeks ago because of side-effects, and I start radiotherapy on Monday. When am I able to start eating bio yogurt, soft cheese, runny eggs etc again?
Posts.Title: When Can I Go off the Avoidance diet?

Posts.Content: I was wondering how do we know our immune system is back to normal now we are no longer having blood tests? Also how much effect does radiotherapy have on our immunity, and is it a good idea to stay on the diet until it is finished too? Probably overthinking, as usual......
Posts.Title: When Can I Go off the Avoidance diet?

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny1973 I had a mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy (SNB) last week, after having lobular features diagnosed in Feb, and an MRI too. I have to say it was much easier than I expected and I'm recovering well. Did they say if the biopsy that showed you have lobular carcinoma, also showed if you are oestrogen positive or negative (ER+ or -), HER2 Positive or negative, or Triple negative? All these can have a factor in whether you might need chemo or radiotherapy afterwards or not. Did they actually say you might need these? I was diagnosed grade 2 and am ER+, HER2-, and my lymph node ultrasound looked clear which is why they only said I needed a mastectomy with SNB.  If it had looked like your nodes could be affected already, you would probably have had an extra underarm node biopsy as well, and then they may have sald you might need full node clearance. However if they are only saying you need SNB that is good, and it is an extra precaution they take to make sure. It is all very confusing to start with I know, so feel free to ask as many questions as you like on here, and I am sure others will be able to advise you too. Best wishes
Posts.Title: waiting for mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy - what about reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, They have said I'll need to stay overnight due to the 24 hour adult to help rule, and I'm trying to organise a lift there on morning of op via volunteer scheme, but hospital is 30 miles & 45min drive away on country roads, so not easy. So far l haven't had any support from the hospital in recommending a solution, so just feeling a bit down about it all...... Not like me at all as I'm usually on top of things I had wondered about how bumpy the bus ride would feel, given it will be an hour, and I have a blow up cushion at the ready for my underarm. Jan
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I'm still awaiting date for surgery (probable WLE & sentinel node biopsy, but that may change depending on what last Friday's MRI showed), but can anyone tell me would an hour long Bus trip home the next day be doable?  Also, were there things you found hard to do afterwards that you didn't expect?
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi 'Snowys Mum' Helen, My family (brothers & their kids) are all in Australia, and my friends are all in the South of England (I'm near the Scottish Borders), so no help there. It is actually one of the main reasons I had been about to put my house on the market for Easter, and move back, due to health reasons (vulval pre-cancer VIN3) that started last year, and the reason I am really annoyed about my diagnosis right now!
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen & Mildredthecat for your kind offers. If I can't get it sorted it may be a taxi - at £50! - ouch! Best wishes
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Thank you both. I retired to where I live 4 years ago, so don't really know anyone nearby. I live on my own, and have always been very independent so not used to asking for help, hence trying to sort out transport options. My house is a mile from the village bus stop, so aim to get a taxi from there. Best of luck for your own treatments too x
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, Have a look at Silima which is the brand I was given in hosp for both softie and prosthesis, both of which are on their site which I was looking at last week. They also do lingerie. Enjoy the rest of your Sunday, Jan
Posts.Title: Buying a prosthetic breast on line.

Posts.Content: Hi Debs, Best wishes for tomorrow, and let us know how you get on. I start FEC-T on the 7th July, also live alone and have always been hugely independent, so reading replies to your post has been helpful to me and I'm sure others, too.  We can all get through it together. Love and hugs, Jan
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo
